{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3400764,"name":"E DiCarlo","username":"E_DiCarlo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/ecae2f/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-21T19:36:49.885Z","cooked":"

I’m a programming mentor (though not a programmer), and my team will be switching to swerve drive during the off season this year. We are programming in java, and we are using Kraken motors with Talon FX controllers, CANCoders, pigeon 2 gyro, and Canivore so we could use the Phoenix Tuner X swerve code generator. However, I am concerned that it has a different API and will be “out of the box” code which could lead us to less understanding of the code and less options/flexibility/examples/success when it comes to creating code for autonomous routines. We have already started learning about java coding for swerve via WPILib information and by watching the Zero to Autonomous video #6 (with accompanying swerve drive code), as well as reviewing the AdvantageKit swerve drive code.
At this point I am inclined to go with trying to implement the AdvantageKit swerve drive code rather than starting with the Tuner X Swerve code. By the way, far in the past we had tried the CTRE Motion Magic for autonomous without much luck.
Any advice here would be greatly appreciated.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-06-21T19:36:49.885Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":213,"reads":346,"readers_count":345,"score":1134.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467845,"topic_slug":"help-need-advice-for-switching-to-swerve-drive-java","display_username":"E DiCarlo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30734,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-need-advice-for-switching-to-swerve-drive-java/467845/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3400789,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-21T20:52:56.212Z","cooked":"

While the AdvantageKit Swerve template is excellent, it is a big decision to switch to using AdvantageKit and it isn’t the right solution for every team. More details here. Personally, I wouldn’t use AdvantageKit unless your team is familiar with traditional logging. If you feel your team could benefit from more advanced logging features like Log Replay, AdvantageKit is a good path for your team to take.

I’m not too familiar with the Tuner X Swerve Generator, however, from their documentation, it seems to be very straightforward with a clear and well documented step by step process.

If I were in your position, I would use the Tuner X Swerve Generator as a starting point, and if you feel that it is difficult to understand/use, look at using something else such as AdvantageKit or a custom swerve base.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-06-21T20:52:56.212Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":299,"readers_count":298,"score":189.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":467845,"topic_slug":"help-need-advice-for-switching-to-swerve-drive-java","display_username":"Elliot Scher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BrzPw6ngx4o","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":20},{"url":"https://github.com/Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit/blob/main/docs/WHAT-IS-ADVANTAGEKIT.md","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"AdvantageKit/docs/WHAT-IS-ADVANTAGEKIT.md at main · Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit · GitHub","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)"},"post_url":"/t/help-need-advice-for-switching-to-swerve-drive-java/467845/2","custom_user_title":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3400806,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-21T21:21:54.710Z","cooked":"

To give a data point as a new programming mentor who went through something similar with our team in April this year (after our season ended), we started with the Rev Robotics code using SDS modules, Neo/SparkMaxes, and CANCoders.

I had never written a line of Java code in my life (but lots of c, C++, and C#, so basic concepts were there) and found that the most difficult (but also most useful) part was figuring out how to use the simulator and tools (including AdvantageScope) to debug the code. I don’t know that one starting point or another will make the difference for you so much as knowing how to use the suite of tools to start with something working, make incremental changes, and all the while being able to observe/debug them using the excellent simulation tools.

There is then one additional step to bridge from the simulated world to the real world (in terms of CANCoder offset calibration, basic CAN wiring/motor control, gyro integration, etc.) but I found that part to all be “just a simple, if annoying, set of tasks,” but nothing that was conceptually challenging.

You have enough time (calendar time, anyway) that you can try multiple starting points and see which one(s) resonate the best with your team of coders. You might even consider a starting point of another team’s published code that is using the same hardware as you’ve chosen. (I’m a big fan of exploring and assign very little cost to off-season exploration of code.)

Thanks to everyone who has replied - this all helps.
I am still concerned that the Tuner X Swerve Code does not look like the swerve code from the WPILib or YAGSL which we have studied and learned to some extent. Does anyone have experience with the Tuner X code?

E_DiCarlo:

does not look like the swerve code from the WPILib or YAGSL

I just took a look at the CTRE swerve generated code for the first time and their style is noticeable for several small container classes and method chaining. I just took a look at YAGSL for the first time and their style seems more similar to the WPILib. (YAGSL does say to use the CTRE swerve for your equipment.)

Is that CTRE style of coding what concerns you or do you think the calculations in the library classes are solving different problems than the WPILib or YAGSL?

They all seemed rather similar to me as they are all solving the same robot movement problem but each has a little different flavor of expressing features, options and embellishments. All should connect to PathPlanner about the same.

We used the Tuner X code - it was a game changer for how fast we could get up and running. We’ve coded swerve before and after using Tuner X we will always use Tuner X in the future.

My concern is the style of coding and classes used. When I reviewed YAGSL, WPILib swerve code examples, and code associated with AdvantageKit, I could follow and understand the code.
When I look at the CTRE SwerveDriveExample code, I cannot follow the much of the code. All of this is new to me, but I reviewed WPILib information on kinematics and odometry, watched the Zero To Autonomous video #6 on Swerve Drive (and reviewed the associated code), and was able to follow that code. I am concerned I will not be able to troubleshoot the CTRE Tuner X code because I don’t have a good understanding of it.

If it’s easy to create the Tuner X code, we can try that first, but I think using the AdvantageKit code (or YAGSL or other similar code) that is written in the usual command-based format using the java classes that were in the tutorials may lead to more success.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T20:00:03.862Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":145,"readers_count":144,"score":39.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467845,"topic_slug":"help-need-advice-for-switching-to-swerve-drive-java","display_username":"E DiCarlo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":39555,"username":"David_IsMe","name":"David B","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/david_isme/{size}/196853_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30734,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-need-advice-for-switching-to-swerve-drive-java/467845/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401081,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T20:08:14.793Z","cooked":"

As others already said, there are more “generic” ways to do so, like using existing libraries (e.g. YAGSL), repurposing code made by a vendor (e.g. CTR template or SDS template), or developing a code on your own.

Our team went the latter route to much success. Our repo is here:

github.com

GitHub - FRC999/2024Competition at 2024PostSeason

2024PostSeason

Contribute to FRC999/2024Competition development by creating an account on GitHub.

We treat our code as educational tool, so we actually used Phoenix 5 (well, because we did not know whether we will get the motors that support Phoenix 6). So, the code is reasonably well documented.

You can also look at our “teaching code” we developed last summer -

GitHub

GitHub - FRC999/2024Swerve

Contribute to FRC999/2024Swerve development by creating an account on GitHub.

this code has pass-through classes for motors and IMU, so like YAGSL, it is compatible with pretty much any hardware, you just need to configure it.
We’re also using Java. Note that Krakens only support Phoenix 6, so your motor code would need to be adjusted a bit, should you decide to use our code as an example.
We’re currently refactoring our code to Phoenix 6. So, will have a functional one within a few weeks.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T20:08:14.793Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":64.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":467845,"topic_slug":"help-need-advice-for-switching-to-swerve-drive-java","display_username":"Alex Tsekhansky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/FRC999/2024Swerve","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - FRC999/2024Swerve","clicks":9},{"url":"https://github.com/FRC999/2024Competition/tree/2024PostSeason","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - FRC999/2024Competition at 2024PostSeason","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-need-advice-for-switching-to-swerve-drive-java/467845/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401108,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T21:56:10.517Z","cooked":"

IMHO the choice of approach to swerve coding (or anything else) depends on your goal.

If your goal is to get going quickly with a black box control, you can push the buttons on the code generator and it will probably work Other people have pushed those same buttons, so there’s no trailblazing risk, and you’ll be able to focus the team on other topics, e.g. mechanics.

On the other hand, if your goal is to use FRC to teach your students about control itself, then it seems like a better approach to work up a solution that the students will understand, and model the sort of problem-solving that they’ll need to use with problem spaces that don’t have pushbutton solutions.

A few years ago, we worked up our first swerve using PWM-controlled DC motors, the simplest steering encoders we could find, and the WPILib example swerve project, and it all worked fine. It was very simple.

Summer is a great time to nudge your students towards deeper understanding of control topics.

From 2021 to 2023 we ran a version of WPIlib/Fusion swerve code.

For 2024 we forked/branched the CTRE swerve library in the fall because the library had a couple of limitations at the time that didn’t allow us to do all the things are previous swerve code could do. I don’t remember what they all were. Understanding the library did take some time but we were able to plug it into our normal command/subsystem structure. However, this meant that we stopped getting automatic updates from CTRE for their swerve library and this caused us to have to discover some issues.

Going forward we are planning to use the CTRE library directly and figure out ways to patch on top of it for any specific features we need.

Our 2024 code is linked below, I’m not saying it’s a good example of what to do, just that it’s possible to use the CTRE code without using their full template.

GitHub

GitHub - Spectrum3847/2024-Ultraviolet: Spectrum's 2024 Competition Software

Spectrum's 2024 Competition Software. Contribute to Spectrum3847/2024-Ultraviolet development by creating an account on GitHub.

We have used several code libraries and I would recommend you start with Tuner X since your HW supports it.

You can still implement cool stuff on top of it such as game piece tracking, Apriltag alignment etc. The APIs are a little different but most of the differences are in the “setup” not the use. Getting the configuration correct is really what you are getting with Tuner X.

While you can learn a lot troubleshooting configuration…. It is also can be a big turn off…. Especially because some changes survive code deploys/restarts but not power cycles, etc.

IMHO, if they are coding they are learning whether they are in the guts of a swerve library or using a COTS library. In really life developers utilize a lot of provided libraries too… so I feel zero guilt about using them.

By the way, an important detail with the advantagekit swerve drive code is that you don’t have to use log replay with it, or even the advantagekit system with it. The traditional way of coding subsystems still works fine(and you can even utilize Logger.recordOutput() and @AutoLogOutput).

However, if you arent planning to utilize the advantagekit system, it might be better to simply use the Tuner X swerve generator + some other logging framework(like monologue or epilogue).

We completed the retrofit to Phoenix 6.

The code is here: GitHub - FRC999/2024Competition at 2024PostSeasonPhoenix6

Note that the retrofit still does not use native Velocity PID, but rather converts velocity into Duty Cycle numbers. So, the logic of the code stays the same.

We’re now working on adopting the native code that is auto-generated by CTR Phoenix Tuner X. That code is native (in a sense that it’s based directly on the CTR libraries), and already uses voltage-based driving and velocity PID. And it’s much-much shorter. So, it looks very promising for the next season. We literally were able to get teleop driving working in 30 minutes from the beginning. We will be converting it to the PRO, though, as we really like the hardware PID and a possibility of the 1kHz update cycle on the turn motor sensors.

My team has tried creating swerve drive code two ways:

  1. TunerX generated code (we are using CTRE CANivore, Kraken motors, CANcoders and Pigeon2 gyro).
  2. Using BaseTalonFXSwerve sample code from Github.

At this point, when we deploy the code we are getting the following messages:
-CAN frame not received / too stale
-Device firmware could not be retrieved.

Everything worked fine during the TunerX code generation, including spinning the drive and turning motors, and reading the encoders and their offsets. The wiring looks fine. Bus utilization is low on the driver station. We have also checked that we have loaded Pheonix 6 on all of the motors and encoders and the gyro.

Does anyone have any ideas?

Also, we are hoping there might be a mentor nearby who would be willing to meet with us (in or near Old Lyme CT) to help get swerve drive started.

Thanks!

Device firmware could not be retrieved indicates the device couldn’t be found. If you are using the Swerve Generator, things should just work as it handles the validation for you.

Are you seeing these messages continuously or just once on startup? If it’s once on startup, try enabling and controlling the robot anyways?

For more debugging:

  • Can you share your generated Tuner X swerve project?
  • Can you take a screenshot of the list of devices in Tuner X?
